case_name: Panchshila Industrial Cooperative Society Multi Unit v. Gurgaon Central Cooperative Bank Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2293 of 1970

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 2293 of 1970.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated May 4, 1970 of the Central Registrar of Co-operative Societies, New Delhi

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave, from the order dated May 4, 1970 of the Central Registrar of Co-operative Societies, New Delhi in Appeal No. CR/1/70.

facts.text: Order in Appeal No. CR/1/70

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave, from the order dated May 4, 1970 of the Central Registrar of Co-operative Societies, New Delhi in Appeal No. CR/1/70.

facts.text: Appellant is Panchshila Industrial Cooperative Society Multi Unit

anchor.surface_text: dismissing the appeal filed by Panchshila Industrial Cooperative Society  Multi Unit  appellant before us against the award passed by the Arbitrator  Deputy Registrar

facts.text: Respondent is Gurgaon Central Cooperative Bank Ltd., Gurgaon

anchor.surface_text: in respect of the dispute between the Gurgaon Central Cooperative Bank Ltd., Gurgaon respondent before us, and the appellant.

facts.text: Award passed by Deputy Registrar of Cooperative Societies Rohtak on October 7, 1969

anchor.surface_text: against the award passed by the Arbitrator  Deputy Registrar of Cooperative Societies Rohtak  dated October 7, 1969, in respect of the dispute

facts.text: Central Registrar dismissed the appeal filed by appellant against the award

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is against the order of the Central Registrar of Cooperative Societies New Delhi dismissing the appeal filed by Panchshila Industrial Cooperative Society

facts.text: Central Registrar held that he was the appropriate appellate authority

anchor.surface_text: The Central Registrar held that he was number the appropriate appellate authority against the award in question.

facts.text: Respondent Bank approached the Registrar of Cooperative Societies Haryana for resolving dispute

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts are these. The respondent Bank approached the Registrar of Cooperative Societies Haryana for resolving a dispute between the Bank and one of its members appellant before us.

facts.text: Registrar by order dated February 17, 1968 referred dispute to Deputy Registrar Rohtak under S.56 Punjab Co-operative Societies Act, 1961

anchor.surface_text: The Registrar by his order dated February 17, 1968, in exercise of the powers vested in him under S. 56 of the Punjab Co-operative Societies Act, 1961, referred the dispute to the Deputy Registrar Cooperative Societies Rohtak for decision.

facts.text: Arbitrator awarded appellant to pay Rs. 16,05,658-20 together with interest at 6.5% per annum on principal Rs. 11,52,535-00 until realisation

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrator gave the award on October 7, 1969, directing that the appellant do pay to the respondent in all Rs. 16,05,658 - 20 together with interest at the rate of six and a half per cent per annum until the realisation of the principal amount viz. Rs. 11,52,535 00.

facts.text: Appellant filed appeal against award before Central Registrar

anchor.surface_text: The appellant as mentioned above filed an appeal against this award before the Central Registrar.

facts.text: Respondent Bank is a co-operative society governed by Punjab Co-operative Societies Act 1961

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Bank is a companyoperative society governed by the provisions of the Punjab Co-operative Societies Act 1961.

facts.text: Appellant registered in December 1955 under Punjab Cooperative Societies Act, 1955

anchor.surface_text: It is however, companytended that the appellant was registered in December 1955 under the Punjab Cooperative Societies Act, 1955,

facts.text: Appellant became multi-unit co-operative society by virtue of States Reorganisation Act, 1956 and S.5A Multi-Unit Co-operative Societies Act, 1942

anchor.surface_text: and by virtue of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, and S. 5A of the Multi-Unit Co-operative Societies Act, 1942, the appellant has ceased to be governed by the provisions of the Punjab Co-operative Societies Act because it has become a multi-unit companyoperative society.

facts.text: Appellant is a member of the respondent Bank

anchor.surface_text: inasmuch as the appellant remains a member of the companyoperative society, namely, the respondent Bank.

facts.text: Dispute between respondent Bank and appellant fell within S.55 Punjab Act

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that the dispute between the respondent Bank and the appellant fell within S. 55 and was properly referred to arbitration under that section.

facts.text: Central Registrar had no jurisdiction to hear the appeal

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear therefore, that the Central Registrar had numberjurisdiction to hear the appeal.

facts.text: Appeal lies under S.68 of Punjab Act 1961 to the Government if decision by Registrar

anchor.surface_text: An appeal against the at award lies under S. 68 of the Punjab Act of 1961 to the Government of the decision or order was made by the Registrar,

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Sikri, C.J.

anchor.surface_text: Harbans Singh, for the appellant. Remeshwar Dial and A.D. Mathur, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Sikri, C. J.-

facts.text: Appeal fails and is dismissed with costs

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.
Appeal by special leave, from the order dated May 4, 1970 of the Central Registrar of Co-operative Societies, New Delhi in Appeal No. CR/1/70.
under S. 56 of the Punjab Co-operative Societies Act, 1961, referred the dispute to the Deputy Registrar Cooperative Societies Rohtak for decision.

concepts.interpretation: Registrar exercised powers under it to refer dispute to Deputy Registrar for decision as arbitrator.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: authority on the facts of this case. The relevant facts are these. The respondent Bank approached the Registrar of Cooperative Societies Ha

concepts.unlisted_description: Power to refer disputes to arbitration

anchor.surface_text: Section 55 1  of this Act inter alia provides that if any dispute touching the constitution management or the business of a co operative society arises between a member and the society such dispute shall be referred to the Re- gistrar for decision and noCourt shall have jurisdiction to entertain any suit or other proceeding in respect of such dispute. Section 55 2  provides that for the purposes of sub-section  1  a claim by the society for any debt or de- mand due to it from a member or the nominee heirs or legal representatives of a deceased member whether such debt or demand be admitted or no, shall be deemed to be a dispute touching the constitution, management or the business of the co-operative society. Sub-section  3  of S. 55 provides that if any question arises whether a dispute referred to the Registrar under this section is or is no a dispute touching the constitution management or the business of a co perative society, the decision thereon of the Registrar shall be final and shall no be called in question in any court.

concepts.interpretation: Covers disputes between member and society including debt claims; Registrar's decision on whether dispute covered is final; ousts civil court jurisdiction.

issues.text: whether the Central Registrar was the appropriate authority on the facts of this case

anchor.surface_text: The only question which arises before us is whether the Central Registrar was the appropriate authority on the facts of this case.

issues.text: whether the dispute between the respondent Bank and the appellant fell within S. 55 and was properly referred to arbitration under that section

anchor.surface_text: There is nodoubt that the dispute between the respondent Bank and the appellant fell within S. 55 and was properly referred to arbitration under that section.

issues.text: whether the appellant has ceased to be governed by the provisions of the Punjab Co-operative Societies Act because it has become a multi-unit cooperative society

anchor.surface_text: It is however, contended that the appellant was registered in December 1955 under the Punjab Cooperative Societies Act, 1955, and by virtue of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, and S. 5A of the Multi-Unit Co-operative Societies Act, 1942, the appellant has ceased to be governed by the provisions of the Punjab Co-operative Societies Act because it has become a multi-unit cooperative society.

issues.text: whether an appeal against the award lies under S. 68 of the Punjab Act of 1961 to the Central Registrar

anchor.surface_text: An appeal against the at award lies under S. 68 of the Punjab Act of 1961 to the Government of the decision or order was made by the Registrar, and to the Registrar if the decision or order was made by any other person. It is quite clear therefore, that the Central Registrar had nojurisdiction to hear the appeal.

issues.text: whether the Central Registrar should not have dismissed the appeal but returned the memorandum of appeal for presentation to the proper authority

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel next contends that the Central Registrar should number have dismissed the appeal but returned the memorandum of appeal for presentation to the proper authority.

arguments.court_reasoning: No statutory provision enabling Central Registrar to return appeal; appropriate authority under Punjab Act will consider S.14 Limitation Act read with S.29(2)

holdings.text: the dispute between the respondent Bank and the appellant fell within S. 55 and was properly referred to arbitration under that section

anchor.surface_text: There is nodoubt that the dispute between the respondent Bank and the appellant fell within S. 55 and was properly referred to arbitration under that section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Debt claim by cooperative society against its member deemed a dispute touching business under S.55(2); Registrar referred under S.56; no civil court jurisdiction under S.55(1)

holdings.text: Multi-Unit Co-operative Societies Act has no impact on S. 55 of the Punjab Co-operative Societies Act, 1961, inasmuch as the appellant remains a member of the co-operative society, namely, the respondent Bank

anchor.surface_text: it has noimpact on S. 55 of the Punjab Co-operative Societies Act, 1961, inasmuch as the appellant remains a member of the companyoperative society, namely, the respondent Bank.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant became multi-unit society but nothing in Multi-Unit Act prevents it from being member of Punjab Act society; S.55 applies to member-society disputes

holdings.text: An appeal against the award lies under S. 68 of the Punjab Act of 1961 to the Government if the decision or order was made by the Registrar, and to the Registrar if the decision or order was made by any other person. [...] the Central Registrar had no jurisdiction to hear the appeal

anchor.surface_text: An appeal against the at award lies under S. 68 of the Punjab Act of 1961 to the Government of the decision or order was made by the Registrar, and to the Registrar if the decision or order was made by any other person. It is quite clear therefore, that the Central Registrar had nojurisdiction to hear the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deputy Registrar (arbitrator) is 'any other person' under S.68, so appeal lies to (Haryana) Registrar, not Central Registrar

holdings.text: There is no statutory provision enabling the Central Registrar to [...] return[ ] the memorandum of appeal for presentation to the proper authority

anchor.surface_text: There is nostatutory provision enabling the Central Registrar to do so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No enabling provision under Punjab Act for return of memorandum when jurisdiction lacking; dismissal appropriate

holdings.text: if an appeal is filed before the appropriate authority under the Punjab Co-operative Societies Act, 1961, that authority will no doubt take into consideration the provisions of S. 14 of the Limitation Act, 1963, read with S. 29(2) and decide whether the appeal should be entertained or no

anchor.surface_text: if an appeal is filed before the appropriate authority under the Punjab Co- operative Societies Act, 1961, that authority will nodoubt take into companysideration the provisions of S. 14 of the Limitation Act, 1963, read with S. 29 2  and decide whether the appeal should be entertained or no.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Advisory on potential condonation of delay in proper forum using Limitation Act provisions applicable via S.29(2)

Dismissal of appeal supports the holding that no provision existed for returning it instead.
Fact of dismissal by Central Registrar directly pertains to and addresses the issue of alternative action (returning the appeal).

The fact of the Central Registrar holding himself as the appropriate appellate authority (a representation by public authority) supports the holding that an appeal to the appropriate authority under the Act will consider relevant statutory provisions, in the context of legitimate expectation doctrine where such representation creates an expectation that must be addressed.
